I love this game on my quest 2, I can play it for hours and hours but it is not perfect and here is why,

- third : to have more choices of rackets in terms of models or choice of colors. This is not a necessity as you don't really notice the racket when you play but it could be a pretty cool option and add some content to the game which in my opinion could be badly needed.

review_feedback:
hi FR4NCIS.QC. Thanks for the review and the suggestions. As far as table size, it is 99.9% or so within actual table dimensions. If the table looks too small, or too large, that is most likely a sign that you are setting the headset FOV to a value that doesn't match your own eyes. Many people end up doing this by accident because the image is clear enough. For many of those people, the range at which the image is clear is actually larger than they may suspect. Anyway, once you set up the FOV to match your real eyes, it should appear correctly sized to you. 
Many players have lined up a real table with the in game table for fun and it does line up very well. 

As far as the other suggestions, all of that and much more is in the works! :)

review_title: Wonderful Recreation of a Fun Game
one_reviews_text:
I just downloaded the game yesterday and have only played a few sets, but as someone who has spent a lot of time playing ping pong IRL, I’ve been very impressed with this app. Just last night I was talking with an opponent about how funny it is that both of us physically tried to avoid hitting the table with our bodies, despite the fact that the table isn’t real, on shots close to the net. 

The devs have done a great job building an immersive world where you truly feel like you are playing ping pong. The physics are also great, and the haptics really make it feel like you’re hitting the ball. The main thing I’ve had difficulty with are slams. But that could be a tracking issue with the touch controllers and not the app itself. 

All in all, I cannot recommend this more highly if you at all enjoy playing ping pong. I’m actually considering buying a second headset for my dad (who is 1800 miles away) so we can play together as I’ve not been able to visit home this year due to COVID.

You can choose to have your microphone on or off and also choose whether you want to hear what your opponent is saying if they have their mic on. They were essentially projecting their frustration on me, which I can understand to some degree because learing the complexities of spin in table tennis is a long term learning experience. What makes it especially difficult as a beginner is that you have to consciously try to figure out what spin is on the ball, then calculate  how to return the ball in play, let alone hit a good shot. Then you have to actually hit the shot! So in the meantime you have to get yourself in position to hit the ball. Its a lot to do in an very short timespan. It can be rather overwhelming, but rewarding as you start to figure it out. It's still an ongoing learning process that I don't really expect to stop. There are some very skilled players out there.  Playing people who are better than you is key to getting better yourself.  They may be taking it easy on you, but that's ok. I call them "Game 3 guys".  I don't let anybody win, but I don't try to crush people either. You should always have to earn it. It feels good to finally get that first win against a tough opponent.

One really-really cool feature in the game is the replay function which allows to slow down/speed up/reverse time. I almost feel like a time-traveller with the ability to walk around the table and controling the time with the flick of the joystick. Really darn cool!!

There are some minor bugs though and I'll list them here:

During replay: 
- It seems like pausing/resuming always resets the time to 00:00, 
- Pressing the left the joystick to the left (and right?) also resets time to 00:00.
Selecting apperance: 
- The "VR helmet" selection is mixed up with the Cat / Rabbit head in the selection window.
Misc:
- It was pretty annoying when I kept getting notifications from other online players even though I was having a single player match against the AI. I later noticed that it is possible to "mute" online requests in the "Multiplayer" selection, so that's good at least. Also, I didn't have much luck with finding a way to mute the annoying multiplayer notification sounds. Not an issue if multiplayer is "muted" all together.

Nevertheless, this ping pong game is awesome in it's simplicity. I can definitly recommend this title to anyone looking for a fast-to-pickup-hard-to-let-go VR game/experience. -1 star for the small bugs, but really, I'm nitpicking! Thanks dev for making this!

review_title: Default settings need to be changed.
one_reviews_text:
The game was unplayable until I turned off spectator and recording options. These options are very resource intensive and do not improve the first person experience, so why are they enabled by default?

I also couldn't reposition myself as the game instructed without enabling in-game positioning in the settings menu. Why tell the player they can reposition immediately, but not enable it by default?

Finally, this is just my opinion, but the floating mask and paddle is incongruous with a realistic environment and immersion breaking. I wish there was options to turn on the head, torso, hands, arms, forearms, etc.

-1 star for the default settings performance.

Update: Only 1 environment.
Multiplayer had syncing issues that made gameplay difficult.
review_feedback:
Hello, thanks for the review and letting us know about the repositioning - I assume you mean the label says you can, but you can't. This was very very recently changed (like a day ago or so) because too many people didn't know of the setting in the menu, and were inadvertently moving themselves around all of the time. 

Regarding performance - I thought we shipped with default spectator mode off, but I'll make sure next patch turns that off. Recording though is negligible. 
We do want to try implementing inverse kinematics (IK), but it's not very simple. It may end up that the best guess arrangement of body and limbs, leads to a worse experience.

review_title: Best sport game currently in VR
one_reviews_text:
Being someone who plays a lot of sport in real life, the accuracy and realism of a game such as this is important to me.  Eleven: Table Tennis is the only game where I genuinely feel that skills are transferrable.

From a fully customisable ball-machine practice mode to mini-games, the opportunities to improve your game are rife - put this alongside a high quality single player mode and this game is as good offline as it is online.  The AI does have some flaws (occasionally falls into a routine of specific shots), but by and large does a great job of simulating a real opponent.  The beginner mode is very simple - basically just gently patting the ball back and forth over the net, and the Legendary mode is incredible - if you are someone who likes to be able to beat a game on its hardest difficulty, then you better be ready to sacrifice a lot of time practicing.  

Getting good will take time.  Getting anything better than rubbish will take time.  But it is so worth it - the sense of satisfaction when you finally learn how to control the spin and can sustain a rally is beyond any other game, because there is no predetermined animation - if something goes wrong, it's your fault.  In this way, this game is more realistic than any other I have played.

The multiplayer works well - I don't use online that much so I can't comment, but the few times I've played with a friend it has worked fine - no lag issues or sync problems.

The devs are very active on the Steam forums.  They are part time, so work doesn't go as quickly as some people would like, but they regularly push updates and seem committed to continuing to support this game, where other devs might have abandoned it as finished and moved on.  

All in all, if you're a fan of table tennis, or sport in general, or if you're really into immersion in VR or simply want to try out something new - I highly recommend this game.

review_title: Best VR Ping Pong Game Available
one_reviews_text: First off, the AI in the game is extremely impressive. Not only is it challenging at higher levels, but the animations make you think you're actually playing with a real person. Very natural motions. The physics are great, and very unforgiving (in other words, if you suck at table tennis in real life, you'll suck at table tennis in this game, too). Good to have a variety of environments to pick from, but the apartment environment definitely feels like the most polished, followed by the winter scene. Haven't run into too many bugs, fewer than some other games I've played.

review_title: The best VR Table Tennis game out there
